newsitem.title: USA: MOTOR RACING-BOESEL EDGES TRACY OUT OF POLE FOR ST LOUIS 300.
newsitem.headline: MOTOR RACING-BOESEL EDGES TRACY OUT OF POLE FOR ST LOUIS 300.

text.p: Brazil's Raul Boesel had just enough speed Friday to edge the tour's hottest driver, Canadian Paul Tracy, out of the pole for Saturday's inaugural St Louis 300 CART race.

Boesel, a former world sports car champion, grabbed his third CART pole -- but first since 1994 in Milwaukee -- with a 24.324-second lap. He averaged 187.963 mph (302.489 kph) in a Reynard Ford around the brand new, four-turn, 1.27 mile (2.04 km) oval just east of St Louis.
Earlier in the session, Tracy, the current CART points leader and winner of the last two races, held the provisional pole with a time of 24.353 seconds in a Penske Mercedes-Benz.

"I knew that my first lap was almost the same as Tracy's," said Boesel. "I knew that I had to go a hair faster, pace myself, especially because sometimes I try to go into turn one too deep and end up losing speed coming out."

Tracy was disappointed at losing the pole position. "I felt that we had more potential in the car, we felt we could squeeze a little (speed out), but the track was slick (in turns one and two) where CART put some sealer to keep it from breaking up.
"As it wore off later in the session it gave the guys who ran later an extra advantage."
But all in all Tracy was not too upset. "I've got more points now after five races than I had the entire last season." He leads the series with 65 points to American Scott Pruett's 61.

Third fastest in the session was another Brazilian, Mauricio Gugelmin. Driving a Reynard Mercedes-Benz in 24.374 seconds, he narrowly missed his first CART pole. "My second lap was a heck of a lap. We came up just a few hundredths (.05) short."
Rounding out the top five were two Canadians, Greg Moore at 24.496 and rookie Patrick Carpentier at 24.546. Both drove Reynard Mercedes-Benz.
Twenty-seven drivers will start the 236-lap, 299.72 mile (482.3 km) race on Saturday.
